bestBHT.bht: The Resurrection of Jesus is central in Paul's gospel and is the central point of Paul's gospel. When the fact of Christ’s resurrection is denied or ignored by nominal Christians, their faith is weak in every respect. For it is the ground of our hope as to eternal life and when Christ comes forth and presents to us in his own resurrection a sure pledge of life, it then appears evident from what fountain the imputation of righteousness flows.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: to whom it shall be imputed, if we believe in him that raised up Jesus our Lord from the dead"
even as Abraham believed that God would raise up a seed in whom all nations should be blessed
in Him that hath done this
Albert Barnes: Faith, now, is belief in God just so far as he has revealed his will to us. It is therefore the same in principle, though it may have reference to different objects.
The main or leading truths that God has made known to us are, that he has given his Son to die; that he has raised him up; and that through him he is ready to pardon.
This is faith under the gospel and shows that the faith of Abraham and of all true believers is substantially the same, and is varied only by the difference of the truths made known.
Marvin Vincent: It shall be reckoned...points to God's definite purpose.
Not the future of the verb to reckon, but mellw to intend.
Who believe. Since we are those who believe.
John Calvin: Paul introduced them, that he might, according to what the passages may require, describe in various ways the real character of faith..." (25 words)
For it is the ground of our hope as to eternal life." (13 words)
When Christ comes forth and presents to us in his own resurrection a sure pledge of life, it then appears evident from what fountain the imputation of righteousness flows." (27 words)
Philip Schaff: The justification of each believer is a single act, but that of believers as a whole is continuous.
The birth of Isaac was a proof of God’s omnipotence, but Christ’s resurrection is a still higher proof.
When the fact of Christ’s resurrection is denied or ignored by nominal Christians, their faith is weak in every respect.
Archibald T. Robertson: The fact of the Resurrection of Jesus is central in Paul's gospel.
The Resurrection of Jesus is central in Paul's gospel.
The Resurrection of Jesus is the central point of Paul's gospel.
John Gill: What was written in the books of the Old Testament, was not written merely on account of them who are the subjects thereof, but for the use, learning, instruction and profit of saints under the New Testament dispensation.
But such as believe as Abraham did, they have the same righteousness imputed to them as he had.
The faith of New Testament believers, and of the object of it.
John Wesley: To establish us in seeking justification by faith, and not by works.
God the Father therefore is the proper object of justifying faith.
St. Paul here, in speaking both of our faith and of the faith of Abraham, puts a part for the whole.

bhtAttempts.bht: The fact of the Resurrection of Jesus is central in Paul's gospel and the Resurrection of Jesus is the central point of Paul's gospel. The birth of Isaac was a proof of God’s omnipotence, but Christ’s resurrection is a still higher proof. When the fact of Christ’s resurrection is denied or ignored by nominal Christians, their faith is weak in every respect. For it is the ground of our hope as to eternal life and when Christ comes forth and presents to us in his own resurrection a sure pledge of life, it then appears evident from what fountain the imputation of righteousness flows. The faith of New Testament believers, and of the object of it, is to establish us in seeking justification by faith, and not by works.

The Resurrection of Jesus is central in Paul's gospel and is the central point of Paul's gospel. The birth of Isaac was a proof of God’s omnipotence, but Christ’s resurrection is a still higher proof. When the fact of Christ’s resurrection is denied or ignored by nominal Christians, their faith is weak in every respect. For it is the ground of our hope as to eternal life and when Christ comes forth and presents to us in his own resurrection a sure pledge of life, it then appears evident from what fountain the imputation of righteousness flows.

The Resurrection of Jesus holds a central place in Paul's gospel, serving as its focal point. It is a powerful demonstration of God's power, surpassing the birth of Isaac. Denying or disregarding the fact of Christ's resurrection shows a weak faith. It is the foundation of our hope of eternal life, giving us a clear understanding of the source of imputed righteousness. Ultimately, the Resurrection of Jesus establishes the significance of seeking justification through faith, not through works.
